newsitem.title: MOROCCO: Arab rights leader calls for more action.
newsitem.headline: Arab rights leader calls for more action.

text.p: An Arab human rights leader on Thursday told activists from around 30 Arab countries that they did too little compared to what oppressed people expected of them, and needed new initiatives.
"What has been achieved so far is too little compared to what oppressed people expect in the Arab World," Adib al-Jadir, the president of the Arab Organisation for Human Rights (AOHR), said.
He was addressing the fourth public assembly of the group being held in the Moroccan capital, Rabat.
Jadir urged the organisation's leadership not to stand in the way of young people who were needed to bring fresh ideas to advance human rights.
"Every leadership should renew itself and allow young, dynamic people, who will live mainly in the next century, to enrich it with new initiatives," he added.

Earlier this month in Cairo, the group issued its report in which it said human rights in the Arab world had worsened in 1996 because of a "triangle of violence" caused by foreign aggression, internal conflicts and the war between governments and Moslem militants.

On Thursday, Mohamed Aouad, an adviser to Morocco's King Hassan, told the session that he deplored the absence of a human rights collective convention in the Arab world and the situation of Palestinians.
"The Arab world so far has not agreed on a collective human rights convention...and Israel still violates human rights in complete contradiction with international law," he said.
AOHR held its meeting in Morocco at the invitation of the Moroccan Human Rights Organisation.
